speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: SCENE I. Verona. A public place.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY, of the house of Capulet, armed with swords and bucklers

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No, for then we should be colliers.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I strike quickly, being moved.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: to the wall.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: to the wall.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: maids, and cut off their heads.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: The heads of the maids?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: take it in what sense thou wilt.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: They must take it in sense that feel it.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: two of the house of the Montagues.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: How! turn thy back and run?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Fear me not.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No, marry; I fear thee!

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: they list.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Enter ABRAHAM and BALTHASAR

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I do bite my thumb, sir.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: [Aside to GREGORY]  Is the law of our side, if I say

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: ay?

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: bite my thumb, sir.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Do you quarrel, sir?

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Quarrel sir! no, sir.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: No better.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Well, sir.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Yes, better, sir.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: You lie.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: They fight

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Enter BENVOLIO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Part, fools!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Put up your swords; you know not what you do.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Beats down their swords

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Enter TYBALT

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Or manage it to part these men with me.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Have at thee, coward!

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: They fight

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Enter, several of both houses, who join the fray; then enter Citizens, with clubs

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Enter CAPULET in his gown, and LADY CAPULET

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter PRINCE, with Attendants

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: With purple fountains issuing from your veins,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: On pain of torture, from those bloody hands

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And hear the sentence of your moved prince.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And made Verona's ancient citizens

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To wield old partisans, in hands as old,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: If ever you disturb our streets again,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: For this time, all the rest depart away:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: You Capulet; shall go along with me:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And, Montague, come you this afternoon,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To know our further pleasure in this case,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Exeunt all but MONTAGUE, LADY MONTAGUE, and BENVOLIO

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Here were the servants of your adversary,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I drew to part them: in the instant came

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: He swung about his head and cut the winds,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Came more and more and fought on part and part,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Till the prince came, who parted either part.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That westward rooteth from the city's side,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: So early walking did I see your son:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And stole into the covert of the wood:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I, measuring his affections by my own,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That most are busied when they're most alone,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Pursued my humour not pursuing his,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Many a morning hath he there been seen,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Should in the furthest east begin to draw

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Away from the light steals home my heavy son,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And private in his chamber pens himself,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And makes himself an artificial night:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Black and portentous must this humour prove,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Have you importuned him by any means?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Both by myself and many other friends:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But he, his own affections' counsellor,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Is to himself--I will not say how true--

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But to himself so secret and so close,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: So far from sounding and discovery,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: As is the bud bit with an envious worm,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: We would as willingly give cure as know.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Exeunt MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Good-morrow, cousin.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is the day so young?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But new struck nine.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay me! sad hours seem long.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Was that my father that went hence so fast?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: In love?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Out--

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Of love?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Out of her favour, where I am in love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O any thing, of nothing first create!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O heavy lightness! serious vanity!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: sick health!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This love feel I, that feel no love in this.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Dost thou not laugh?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: No, coz, I rather weep.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Good heart, at what?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: At thy good heart's oppression.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why, such is love's transgression.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What is it else? a madness most discreet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A choking gall and a preserving sweet.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell, my coz.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Soft! I will go along;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Groan! why, no.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But sadly tell me who.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She will not stay the siege of loving terms,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That when she dies with beauty dies her store.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For beauty starved with her severity

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Cuts beauty off from all posterity.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To merit bliss by making me despair:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, teach me how I should forget to think.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: By giving liberty unto thine eyes;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Examine other beauties.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'Tis the way

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To call hers exquisite, in question more:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He that is strucken blind cannot forget

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Show me a mistress that is passing fair,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What doth her beauty serve, but as a note

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Exeunt
